newsitem.title: FRANCE: French minister wants eco-tax to fight pollution.
newsitem.headline: French minister wants eco-tax to fight pollution.

text.p: French Environment Minister Dominique Voynet, the first Green to hold the post, said in an interview on Thursday she wanted to introduce an "eco-tax" on energy to fight against worsening air quality.

Voynet told the daily Le Figaro that pollution alerts this week in Paris and other large cities were only "the tip of the iceberg" and that France had to take longer-term measures against rising pollution levels.

Pollution alerts were in force for the third straight day in the French cities of Paris, Lyon, Lille and Strasbourg on Thursday due to a mix of persistent high temperatures, sunlight, car exhaust fumes and a lack of wind, the Environment Ministry announced in mid-afternoon.
The ministry renewed a warning to the elderly, small children and people with respiratory problems to limit their physical activity, and an "invitation" to drivers to leave their cars at home.
But pollution was not severe enough to trigger mandatory curbs on cars and free public transport, it said.
Voynet, in the interview, said the French tax system did not differentiate between cleaner energy sources such as liquefied petroleum gas and more polluting ones such as diesel fuel.
"I would like France to adopt an eco-tax on energy and carbon emissions to promote behaviour that respects health and the environment more," she told Figaro.
"It would not be an extra tax, but a tax that could gradually replace part of the tax system," she said. "The prime minister has set up a working group on this issue."
Voynet, who did not give more details of her tax ideas, said the main cause of pollution was the priority that urban planning gave to automobiles over public transport.

She said all cities with more than 100,000 inhabitants would have to draw up a plan by late 1998 to shift the emphasis towards public transport and non-polluting alternatives such as bicycles or walking.
Voynet said she also favoured stricter automobile emission norms and supported efforts within the European Union to introduce them community-wide by the year 2000.
